column2: The 2017 fellowships focused on digital humanities projects and open educational resources. Key projects included visualizing citizen testimony for Idaho Wilderness documentation, the development of Lost Lit Lab, and CTRL+Shift (a data-driven exploration of poet interviews). ThinkOpen fellows worked on creating open educational resources for courses in Music Theory, Psychology, Education, and Mathematics.
column3: Projects in 2018 expanded to include diverse digital collections and social issues. Notable projects included the Voices of Gay Rodeo oral history project, the Historical Japanese Comparative Ceramics Collection, and a visual essay on the closure of the Syringa Mobile Home park. ThinkOpen fellowships supported seven courses across various disciplines, including Chemistry, Music Theory, Physics, and Geography.
column4: 2019 saw a focus on local history and cultural projects, including the Leonard Feather Blindfold Tests digital collection, Idaho Public Archaeology project, and work with the Potlatch Historical Society Collection. ThinkOpen fellows developed culturally responsive materials, including resources for teaching Indigenous histories and Latin American culture.
column5: The year featured projects documenting local environmental and cultural history, including 'Storying Extinction' about North Idaho's Mountain Caribou and oral history interviews with Jazz Festival figure Doc Skinner. ThinkOpen fellowships supported diverse courses including Nuclear Engineering, Education, and Women's Studies.
column6: Projects ranged from digital exhibitions to database creation, including work on the Ella Fitzgerald Collection, Digital Dramaturgy, and the Ghana Music and Dance Initiative. The League of Women Voters archives were processed, and ThinkOpen fellows created resources for courses in Decision Theory, Criminology, and Film Studies.
column7: Fellowship work included creating a digital exhibit of Doc Cheatham's jazz legacy, translating Carl Davidoff's historic cello instruction manual, and processing collections related to science fiction and women in natural resources. ThinkOpen fellows focused on improving existing open educational resources and creating zero-cost course materials.
column8: Fellows worked on diverse environmental and historical projects including wolf reintroduction documentation, Western and Clark's Grebe breeding data, and geo-rectifying historical Idaho aerial photographs. The Latah County Historic Sites Digital Map Project created an interactive resource for local history.
column9: 2024 fellowships encompassed diverse digital humanities and archival projects. Key initiatives included exploring Alice Coltrane's jazz spiritualism through rare oral history recordings, creating a multimodal essay on institutionalization and family archives (Tender Spaces), and processing significant collections including WWAMI and Plant, Soil, and Entomological Sciences materials. ThinkOpen fellows developed zero-cost syllabi for courses in English Grammar, Social Problems, Homicide, and Climate Futures. The year also featured extensive oral history transcription work and archival processing across multiple disciplines.
column10: 2025 fellowships focus on environmental archives, digital storytelling, and historical research. Projects include developing classroom space-based archival curriculum, creating a multimodal exploration of Colorado River ecosystem sedimentation, researching campus building namesakes, and processing significant archival collections including Dr. Richard Wells papers, Forest Service historic photos, and Wildlife Resources Department records. A comprehensive wilderness/environmental archive survey aims to identify Special Collections holdings for future digital initiatives.
